The clustering of mid and high-Alfvénicity saturation points suggests a characteristic threshold around |σc| = 0.6 that may represent the transition from partially open to fully open magnetic topologies, corresponding to the boundary between slow Alfvénic Slow Wind (ASW) and classical fast wind.

figures.short_title: Saturation Slopes vs Alfvnicity

summary.what_we_see:
This two-panel figure shows how the steepness of helium abundance increase with solar wind speed (the saturation slope) depends on Alfvénicity, with color indicating the compressibility level of the plasma. Panel (a) maps compressibility to Alfvénicity using the saturation speed, while panel (b) uses the saturation abundance for mapping. Both axes show saturation slope in units of percent helium per kilometer per second—essentially how quickly helium abundance rises as wind speed increases above the saturation point. Markers are mostly unfilled except for the critical |δnH/nH| = 0.085 compressibility level (shown filled). Colors span from magenta (highly compressible, |δnH/nH| ≈ 0.15) at one extreme to blue (incompressible, |δnH/nH| ≈ 0.02) at the other. Dotted lines connect markers to guide the eye.

Both panels reveal a striking bimodal distribution. In panel (a), most of the compressible solar wind (magenta markers) clusters tightly at low Alfvénicity (|σc| ≈ 0.48-0.52) with steep saturation slopes around 0.006% per km/s. These slopes then plummet rapidly as Alfvénicity increases, with all incompressible cases (blue through yellow markers) converging to a nearly flat slope of about 0.001% per km/s at |σc| = 0.60. Panel (b) shows similar behavior but with the transition spread over a wider Alfvénicity range: compressible wind spans |σc| ≈ 0.5-0.58 with steep slopes, while incompressible wind reaches |σc| ≈ 0.65 with flat slopes. The filled markers tracking the intermediate compressibility level show a smooth transition between these two regimes in both panels.

This bimodal pattern reveals that only compressible, non-Alfvénic solar wind shows substantial helium enrichment with increasing speed above saturation. In this regime, every 100 km/s increase in wind speed corresponds to roughly 0.6% increase in helium abundance—a strong compositional gradient. In contrast, Alfvénic wind shows almost no helium enrichment with speed above saturation (slopes near 0.001% per km/s mean helium is essentially constant). The fact that the transition occurs around |σc| = 0.6 in both panels, despite using different mapping methods, confirms this represents a real physical threshold. Below this threshold, magnetic field structure allows continued fractionation and helium enrichment in fast wind. Above it, helium abundance is locked near the saturation value regardless of speed, suggesting different source heating or acceleration mechanisms.
summary.the_finding:
- Compressible solar wind shows steep saturation slopes around 0.006% per km/s, meaning helium abundance increases substantially with speed above saturation

- Incompressible solar wind shows flat slopes near 0.001% per km/s, meaning helium abundance barely changes with speed above saturation

- When mapped using saturation speed, compressible wind has |σc| < 0.575 while incompressible wind has |σc| ≈ 0.60

- When mapped using saturation abundance, compressible wind has |σc| < 0.6 while incompressible wind has |σc| ≈ 0.65

- The transition between steep and flat slopes is abrupt, occurring over a narrow Alfvénicity range around |σc| = 0.5-0.65
summary.why_it_matters: The saturation slope quantifies how helium composition evolves in the fast solar wind regime. The bimodal distribution demonstrates that Alfvénic wind from open magnetic fields maintains nearly constant helium abundance across all speeds above saturation, while non-Alfvénic wind continues to fractionate and enrich helium as speed increases. This difference likely reflects distinct acceleration mechanisms: Alfvénic wind may be accelerated primarily by wave pressure that affects hydrogen and helium equally, preserving the saturation composition, while non-Alfvénic wind may experience thermal or pressure-driven acceleration that preferentially accelerates lighter hydrogen, leaving helium relatively behind and creating an apparent enhancement. The consistency of the |σc| ≈ 0.6 threshold across both mapping methods validates that Alfvénicity is the fundamental controlling parameter. This threshold may mark the transition from partially open coronal structures that allow continued fractionation to fully open structures where wave-driven acceleration dominates.

figures.short_title: Saturation vs Compressibility

summary.what_we_see:
This two-panel figure presents the reverse perspective of Figure 22, showing how saturation speed (panel a) and saturation abundance (panel b) vary with plasma compressibility, with marker colors now indicating the Alfvénicity level. Colors range from blue (highly Alfvénic, |σc| ≈ 0.0) through cyan, green, yellow, orange, to magenta (non-Alfvénic, |σc| ≈ 1.0). All markers are filled, connected by dotted lines, and surrounded by error bars and a semitransparent gray uncertainty envelope. Horizontal cyan bands mark distinct Alfvénicity regimes (Low, Mid, High |σc|) defined in the companion Paper I. The x-axis spans compressibility from highly incompressible (0.07) to moderately compressible (0.14), capturing the range where saturation transitions occur.

Panel (a) shows saturation speed clustering tightly around 430 km/s for low compressibility (|δnH/nH| < 0.085), with all Mid and High Alfvénicity markers (cyan through orange) confined to this region. As compressibility increases beyond 0.085, saturation speed drops precipitously, with Low Alfvénicity markers (magenta) extending down to 410 km/s at the highest compressibilities. The transition is sharp and systematic, with speed decreasing roughly 20 km/s over a compressibility increase of just 0.04. Panel (b) reveals a strikingly linear relationship between saturation abundance and compressibility: abundance decreases from about 4.2% at the highest compressibility to 3.8% at the lowest, with a fitted slope of -8.6% per unit compressibility. The Mid Alfvénicity markers form a tight cluster along this trend, while Low and High Alfvénicity markers show more scatter but follow the same general relationship.

Together, the panels demonstrate that compressibility is a more fundamental organizing parameter than Alfvénicity for the saturation abundance. While Figure 22 showed how saturation properties vary with Alfvénicity, this figure reveals that when organized by compressibility instead, a cleaner relationship emerges for abundance. The linear trend in panel (b) suggests a direct physical coupling: more compressible plasma reaches saturation at higher helium abundances, while incompressible plasma saturates at lower abundances. The clustering of Mid and High Alfvénicity cases at low compressibility (< 0.085) indicates these regimes naturally produce similar plasma properties. The fact that no saturation points appear at very high compressibility (> 0.14) suggests this represents an upper physical limit on compressibility in the slow-to-fast wind transition.
summary.the_finding:
- Mid and High Alfvénicity solar wind clusters tightly at low compressibility (|δnH/nH| < 0.085) with saturation speeds around 430 km/s

- Low Alfvénicity solar wind extends to higher compressibility levels with saturation speeds dropping to 410 km/s

- Saturation abundance decreases linearly with decreasing compressibility, with slope -8.6±0.5% per unit compressibility

- Extrapolating to perfectly incompressible plasma yields saturation abundance of 4.76±0.04%

- No saturation points observed at compressibility above 0.14, suggesting this represents a physical upper limit

- Compressibility derived from abundance measurements shows tighter clustering than compressibility derived from speed measurements
summary.why_it_matters: This figure demonstrates that compressibility may be a more fundamental parameter than Alfvénicity for understanding helium fractionation in the slow-to-fast wind transition. The linear relationship between saturation abundance and compressibility (panel b) suggests a direct mechanistic coupling: compressible turbulent fluctuations may enhance the gravitational settling or Coulomb drag processes that deplete helium in slow wind, requiring higher abundances before fast wind acceleration becomes efficient. The y-intercept of 4.76% represents the saturation abundance in hypothetical perfectly smooth (incompressible) solar wind, close to the observed value in highly Alfvénic streams. The absence of saturation points at very high compressibility suggests that beyond |δnH/nH| ≈ 0.14, plasma either never reaches the fast wind regime or transitions through different mechanisms. The tight clustering of Mid Alfvénicity cases demonstrates that this regime represents a characteristic equilibrium state for typical solar wind conditions, while Low and High Alfvénicity regimes show more variability reflecting diverse source region properties.

figures.short_title: Helium Enhancement at 800 km/s

summary.what_we_see:
This single-panel figure plots the helium abundance in very fast solar wind (800 km/s—the fastest speed analyzed) relative to the saturation abundance, showing how this enhancement ratio depends on Alfvénicity. Each data point represents a different Alfvénicity level, with colors transitioning from blue (highly Alfvénic, |σc| near 0) through cyan, green, yellow, orange, to dark red and magenta (non-Alfvénic, |σc| near 1.0). The y-axis shows abundance enhancement above saturation, where a value of 1.0 would mean helium abundance at 800 km/s equals the saturation value, while 1.4 would mean 40% enrichment. Error bars indicate uncertainties in the measurements, and a dashed black line shows a linear fit to the overall trend, which has a clear negative slope.

The data reveal a striking linear anti-correlation between Alfvénicity and helium enhancement in fast wind. At the highest Alfvénicity (|σc| ≈ 0.9-1.0), helium abundance in 800 km/s wind exceeds saturation by only 10-11% (ratio ≈ 1.10), shown by the dark red and magenta markers on the right. As Alfvénicity decreases moving left across the plot, enhancement increases systematically: at moderate Alfvénicity (|σc| ≈ 0.5, yellow markers), enhancement reaches about 24%, and at the lowest Alfvénicity (|σc| < 0.1, dark blue markers), enhancement peaks at 37-40%. The linear fit has a slope of -0.4±0.02 per unit |σc| and a y-intercept of 1.46±0.02, meaning that in hypothetical perfectly non-Alfvénic solar wind (|σc| = 0), helium would be enhanced by 46% above saturation.

This linear trend creates an apparent paradox that motivates the entire paper. Fast solar wind above saturation is expected to come from magnetically open coronal holes, which typically produce Alfvénic, incompressible plasma. Yet this figure shows that if the fastest wind were non-Alfvénic, helium would reach 46% above saturation—combined with the saturation value itself being about 50% of photospheric abundance, this would imply helium approaching 73% of photospheric values, contradicting the robust observational finding that solar wind helium never exceeds 50% of photospheric abundance across the solar cycle. The resolution, as explored in the full paper, is that compressibility and Alfvénicity are tightly coupled: non-Alfvénic wind is also compressible, and this compressibility regulates helium abundance through mechanisms that prevent the extrapolated 46% enhancement from being realized in actual observations.
summary.the_finding:
- Helium enhancement above saturation in 800 km/s wind decreases linearly with increasing Alfvénicity, from 40% enhancement in non-Alfvénic wind to 10% in highly Alfvénic wind

- Linear fit yields slope of -0.4±0.02 and y-intercept of 1.46±0.02, indicating 46% theoretical enhancement in perfectly non-Alfvénic wind

- Most Alfvénic solar wind (|σc| > 0.9) shows helium abundance only 10% above saturation even at 800 km/s

- The enhancement varies by a factor of 4 across the Alfvénicity range (10% to 40%)

- The systematic trend suggests fundamental coupling between magnetic topology, wave activity, and compositional fractionation
summary.why_it_matters: This figure exposes a critical tension in solar wind physics: extrapolating the observed trend suggests non-Alfvénic fast wind should have helium abundances exceeding the known 50% photospheric limit. The resolution lies in recognizing that non-Alfvénic and Alfvénic solar wind represent fundamentally different source regions with different magnetic topologies. Alfvénic fast wind from continuously open coronal holes undergoes efficient wave-driven acceleration that reaches high speeds with minimal additional helium fractionation above saturation, resulting in low enhancement. Non-Alfvénic wind from intermittently open or complex magnetic structures experiences continued compositional evolution even above saturation, but the compressibility associated with non-Alfvénic conditions ultimately limits how much helium can accumulate through regulatory mechanisms explored in the paper. This figure demonstrates that source region magnetic topology, as encoded in Alfvénicity and compressibility, fundamentally controls not just the saturation point but the entire compositional evolution of solar wind from slow to fast regimes.
